candidates.label: Assistants become ad-tech; ad-tech becomes governance

odditude.why: The weirdness is the coupling: monetization primitives (identity, targeting, attribution) are the same primitives used for compliance and state pressure—business model choices become governance architecture.

itchiness.why: High volatility × impact: ad rollouts, platform defaults, and regulatory action can flip incentives fast and reshape the assistant ecosystem within a quarter.

sexappeal.why: Ads-in-ChatGPT is instantly legible and debate-friendly; tying it to surveillance and antitrust makes it more urgent and story-shaped.

candidates.label: Child safety accelerates biometric ID rails

odditude.why: Not surprising that safety pushes verification, but the speed and cross-domain alignment (platform policy + litigation + govt biometrics) is notable.

itchiness.why: Legal outcomes and ‘age assurance’ mandates can force product redesigns and vendor lock-in; backlash cycles are sharp.

sexappeal.why: Biometrics + kids + platforms is a durable attention magnet, especially when paired with concrete policy changes like face-scan requirements.

odditude.why: Replacing negotiated trust with sensor+model inference is structurally strange: ‘verification’ becomes a private capability rather than a shared institution.

itchiness.why: Meaningful but slower-moving; adoption and doctrine shift over months/years, with punctuated spikes during crises.

sexappeal.why: High stakes but abstract; needs a crisp framing (e.g., “treaties replaced by dashboards”) to travel.
